slides.title: The Job Lifecycle
slides.ocrText: The Job Lifecycle

slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

« Describe how the special job components
function during the lifecycle of a job
• Configure a job process

slides.title: i Review: Jobs
slides.originalNotes:
Review: Jobs
The term "policy transaction" is more typical in the industry and is used in the user interface. The term "job" is used in the data model, in user interface configuration, and in business rules. All jobs have an issue date and an effective date. For example, you could create a submission job today and issue it tomorrow, that will not take effect until Monday of next week- Tomorrow would be the issue date, but Monday of next week is the effective date. Also referred to as the "Transaction Close Date" in the Transactions list.
A policy transaction is used to execute a transaction. Once it completes, it becomes a transaction on the policy but has an associated policy transaction number.
slides.notes:
Review: Jobs
The term "policy transaction" is more typical in the industry and is used in the user interface. The term "job" is used in the data model, in user interface configuration, and in business rules. All jobs have an issue date and an effective date. For example, you could create a submission job today and issue it tomorrow, that will not take effect until Monday of next week- Tomorrow would be the issue date, but Monday of next week is the effective date. Also referred to as the "Transaction Close Date" in the Transactions list.
A policy transaction is used to execute a transaction. Once it completes, it becomes a transaction on the policy but has an associated policy transaction number.
slides.ocrText:
i Review: Jobs

eee ooe
submission submission
transaction job

• Policy Transactions are represented in PolicyCenter by Jobs
• “Policy Transaction” and “Transaction” are used in the user interface
« “Job” is used throughout the configuration

• Jobs coordinate all of the work associated with creating a new policy and
modifying the policy

slides.title: i Review: Policy transactions
slides.originalNotes:
Review: Policy transactions
Policy transactions coordinate all the work associated with creating a new policy and modifying the policy, e.g., renewal for a new term or cancellation of a policy- The only transaction not included in the slide is an audit Audits can occur at any time during a policy term. A final audit may take place at the end of each policy term. Each of the above transactions are discussed in the following slides.

slides.title: <Jobtype> entities
slides.originalNotes:
<Jobtype> entities
The job object is an entity in PolicyCenter and contains fields and arrays. Methods may be created on an enhancement to the Job type.
All job types create a branch of new PolicyPeriod All jobs except for Audit attempt to bind/promote their branches.
You cannot create a custom Job type. While you can create a subtype of Job, it will not introduce a new into the system-
slides.notes:
<Jobtype> entities
The job object is an entity in PolicyCenter and contains fields and arrays. Methods may be created on an enhancement to the Job type.
All job types create a branch of new PolicyPeriod All jobs except for Audit attempt to bind/promote their branches.
You cannot create a custom Job type. While you can create a subtype of Job, it will not introduce a new into the system-
slides.ocrText:
| <Jobtype> entities

• Job is the parent entity

* Subtypes include Submission,
PolicyChange, Cancellation, Renewal,
Audit, etc.

« <Jobtype> object
• Is instantiated when the job is started
« Executes a transaction on the policy
* Contains required data

* Can be enhanced or extended

slides.title: i Branches
slides.originalNotes:
Branches
Technically, a branch is the directed graph whose root is a Policy Period object. There could be more than one branch if multi-version or side by side is used in a job. But only one version is selected, which can be accessed through Job. Selected Version-
slides.notes:
Branches
Technically, a branch is the directed graph whose root is a Policy Period object. There could be more than one branch if multi-version or side by side is used in a job. But only one version is selected, which can be accessed through Job. Selected Version-

* The job creates a branch Premium

slides.title: i Job processes
slides.originalNotes:
Job processes
PolicyCenter uses both workflows and job process- Job processes are editable. The JobProcess.gs Gosu class contains methods that are common to all jobs and can be viewed in Studio- For example, consider the job process steps involved in a submission job process. The SubmissionProcess.gs class exists in Guidewire Studio and has the actions taken within a submission job.
slides.notes:
Job processes
PolicyCenter uses both workflows and job process- Job processes are editable. The JobProcess.gs Gosu class contains methods that are common to all jobs and can be viewed in Studio- For example, consider the job process steps involved in a submission job process. The SubmissionProcess.gs class exists in Guidewire Studio and has the actions taken within a submission job.

i Job processes

Submission process snippet

| Fulsee File submission —_ submission Pg «osavedraft fe Bind and Issue

« Ajob process controls the flow of a job by using:
* Gosu classes such as SubmissionProcess.gs
« Wizard actions that can directly interact with the job and policy revisions
+ Workflows

• Job processes are flexible for user-driven logic

slides.title: i <Jobtype>Process classes
slides.originalNotes:
<Jobtype>Process classes
<Jobtype>Processes are not entities in PolicyCenter, but Gosu classes-
slides.notes:
<Jobtype>Process classes
<Jobtype>Processes are not entities in PolicyCenter, but Gosu classes-
slides.ocrText:
i <Jobtype>Process classes

* Contain methods required for processing the job

• Sub classes of JobProcess include SubmissionProcess,
RenewalProcess, AuditProcess, CancellationProcess, etc.

* In Studio, configuration > gsrc > gw > job
• Instantiated when methods are required

* Maintained in cache

Le

slides.title: i <Jobtype> wizards
slides.originalNotes:
<Jobtype> wizards
The Job Wizard Helper is not visible in Studio because it is a Java class, not Gosu. JobWizardHelperEnhancem ent class is visible and can be edited

Visibility of buttons is discussed later in this lesson.
slides.notes:
<Jobtype> wizards
The Job Wizard Helper is not visible in Studio because it is a Java class, not Gosu. JobWizardHelperEnhancem ent class is visible and can be edited

Visibility of buttons is discussed later in this lesson.
slides.ocrText:
i <Jobtype> wizards G
• <Jobtype> Wizards contain screens, tools, and buttons that help =
the user step through the life cycle of the job —
• Job Wizard Helper

* Is a Java class that provides functionality for job wizards, such as | )

+ Movement between steps

+ Visibility based on state of job
* Helper methods for adding messages
* Has a Gosu enhancement that can be edited to provide additional functionality
* Each job type has a Job Wizard Button Set containing relevant buttons

• Buttons call Gosu code to perform the work of the job

D>

* Buttons appear in the job wizard’s screens only if they are currently relevant

slides.title: i Workflows
slides.originalNotes:
Workflows
In short, workflows enable processes that need to wait for something before proceeding.
slides.notes:
Workflows
In short, workflows enable processes that need to wait for something before proceeding.
slides.ocrText:
i Workflows

• Integration with users and external systems
« “Wait for user to respond before proceeding”
« “Wait for billing system to respond before proceeding”
* Time-delayed actions
* Relative: “Wait three weeks before proceeding”
« Absolute: “Wait until (effectiveDate) before proceeding” _78

Fl— 8

slides.title: Starting a job
slides.originalNotes:
Starting a job
For example, an insurer’s billing system might triggera cancellation job for apolicy whose premiums have not been paid on time. The Renewal jobs and Audit jobs can be started by the batch processes.
slides.notes:
Starting a job
For example, an insurer’s billing system might triggera cancellation job for apolicy whose premiums have not been paid on time. The Renewal jobs and Audit jobs can be started by the batch processes.
slides.ocrText:
| Starting a job

Jobs can be started in three ways

+ By users through the Actions menu @,
—

* By external systems through APIs =a

* Through PolicyCenter batch processes

Op

Note that the job wizard itself does not typically create the job object but receives it as a parameter. The example is from StartPolicyChange.pcf.

slides.title: i Checking job conditions
slides.originalNotes:
Checking job conditions
For example, each of the methods on the Job Conditions object in JobProcess. canEdit() checks a possible error condition for editing- If that error condition is true, it appends a message to the U messages" string builder, which begin sempty. If the final U messages" string is not empty, the Job Conditions. Okay() property evaluates to false, and the Edit Policy Transaction button is not visible in the user interface.

The can methods that check for job conditions are used not only in the job wizard user interface, but also called from the automaticprocesses though APIsand batch processes before each job function is executed- For example, check canRequestQuote before calling requestQuote() or canBind() before bind()-

The JobConditions object is set to @ReadOnly This means that you cannot revise any of the existing methods and properties-However, you can create an enhancement which contains any additionalmethods and properties you may require-
slides.notes:
Checking job conditions
For example, each of the methods on the Job Conditions object in JobProcess. canEdit() checks a possible error condition for editing- If that error condition is true, it appends a message to the U messages" string builder, which begin sempty. If the final U messages" string is not empty, the Job Conditions. Okay() property evaluates to false, and the Edit Policy Transaction button is not visible in the user interface.

The can methods that check for job conditions are used not only in the job wizard user interface, but also called from the automaticprocesses though APIsand batch processes before each job function is executed- For example, check canRequestQuote before calling requestQuote() or canBind() before bind()-

The JobConditions object is set to @ReadOnly This means that you cannot revise any of the existing methods and properties-However, you can create an enhancement which contains any additionalmethods and properties you may require-
slides.ocrText:
i Checking job conditions

• Preconditions are checked before a job function is performed
• Button visibility in the job wizards is based on canXXX methods in job process classes
+ For example, in JobWizardToolBarButtonSet.Submission.pcf
+ The Edit Policy Transaction button’s visible property calls JobProcess.canEdit().Okay()
* Can methods return a JobConditions object
* JobConditions object Checks for error conditions

* Contains a string builder called “_messages” which begins empty and is built by error
condition checks

* If “_messages” remains empty, derived property “Okay” returns true, otherwise, false

slides.title: i Executing business logic
slides.originalNotes:
Executing business logic Examples:
Job Wizard Toolbar ButtonSet –Sub mission. pcf, the action property calls methods on the job process, wizard, and wizard helper objects.

Renewal Process. start(). One method can call many others. Rather than a simple straight line or chain, it can become a pretty complex web.

Cancellation Process finish end Notices() starts workflow

Complete Cancellation WF, which waits to issue the cancellation on the Cancellation Date or ends the process if the cancellation is rescinded.
In the
Complete CancellationWF workflow, it calls
CancellationProcess-issueC ancellationFromWorkflow().
slides.notes:
Executing business logic Examples:
Job Wizard Toolbar ButtonSet –Sub mission. pcf, the action property calls methods on the job process, wizard, and wizard helper objects.

Renewal Process. start(). One method can call many others. Rather than a simple straight line or chain, it can become a pretty complex web.

Cancellation Process finish end Notices() starts workflow

Complete Cancellation WF, which waits to issue the cancellation on the Cancellation Date or ends the process if the cancellation is rescinded.
In the
Complete CancellationWF workflow, it calls
CancellationProcess-issueC ancellationFromWorkflow().
slides.ocrText:
i Executing business logic

* Job wizard buttons call methods

* They can call methods on any object available in the current context

* Such as <Jobtype>Process, <Jobtype>Wizard, JobWizardHelper, PolicyPeriod
• Job process methods call other methods
* Job process methods call workflows

• Workflows call job process methods

slides.title: End of ajob
slides.originalNotes:
End of a job
Note that Audit jobs are an exception. The Audit job does not promote, withdraw, or discard a branch, but ends when the audit is completed.
slides.notes:
End of a job
Note that Audit jobs are an exception. The Audit job does not promote, withdraw, or discard a branch, but ends when the audit is completed.
slides.ocrText:
| End of ajob

« Job ends when the branch is
* Promoted (bound)
« Withdrawn
* Discarded
• Job object remains in the database, where it can be referenced
* It can no longer be edited

• Job process object is discarded

slides.title: i Configuring job processes
slides.ocrText:
i Configuring job processes Ga

1. Extend the <Jobtype> related classes and PCF files, for example
« JobEnhancement.gs, SubmissionEnhancement.gs, SubmissionProcess.gs
* SubmissionWizard.pcf and related screens

2. Configure the business logic

a) Edit existing functions to capture your business process

b) Create additional functions as needed

questionData.answer: What two classes exist for every job type? The job class and the job process class.

Answer Gi
What two classes exist for every job type?

The job class and the job process class.

slides.title: Question
slides.ocrText:
Question G
When does a job end?
•
SS oe ee oe oe oo

questionData.question: When does a job end?
questionData.answer: When the job’s branch is promoted, withdrawn, or discarded.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer Gi
When does a job end?
•
•
When the job’s branch is promoted, withdrawn, or discarded.
SS Se ee eee eo
